name: 1607_E. Robot on the Board 1
description:
The robot is located on a checkered rectangular board of size n × m (n rows, m columns). The rows in the board are numbered from 1 to n from top to bottom, and the columns — from 1 to m from left to right.

The robot is able to move from the current cell to one of the four cells adjacent by side.

The sequence of commands s executed by the robot is given. Each command is denoted by one of the symbols 'L', 'R', 'D' or 'U', and triggers the movement to left, right, down or up, respectively.

The robot can start its movement in any cell. The robot executes the commands starting from the first one, strictly in the order in which they are listed in s. If the robot moves beyond the edge of the board, it falls and breaks. A command that causes the robot to break is not considered successfully executed.

The robot's task is to execute as many commands as possible without falling off the board. For example, on board 3 × 3, if the robot starts a sequence of actions s="RRDLUU" ("right", "right", "down", "left", "up", "up") from the central cell, the robot will perform one command, then the next command will force him to cross the edge. If the robot starts moving from the cell (2, 1) (second row, first column) then all commands will be executed successfully and the robot will stop at the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

<image> The robot starts from cell (2, 1) (second row, first column). It moves right, right, down, left, up, and up. In this case it ends in the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

Determine the cell from which the robot should start its movement in order to execute as many commands as possible.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

Example

Input


4
1 1
L
1 2
L
3 3
RRDLUU
4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output


1 1
1 2
2 1
3 2
prompt:
The robot remains on a checkered rectangular board with dimensions n × m (n rows, m columns). Rows on the board are indexed from 1 to n starting from the top down, and columns are indexed from 1 to m starting from the left across.

The robot is able to move from the current cell to one of the four cells adjacent by side.

The sequence of commands s executed by the robot is given. Each command is denoted by one of the symbols 'L', 'R', 'D' or 'U', and triggers the movement to left, right, down or up, respectively.

The robot can start its movement in any cell. The robot executes the commands starting from the first one. It does so strictly in the order in which they are listed in s. If the robot moves beyond the edge of the board, it falls and breaks. A command that causes the robot to break is not considered successfully executed.

The robot's task is to execute as many commands as possible without falling off the board. For instance, on board 3 × 3, if the robot starts a sequence of actions s="RRDLUU" ("right", "right", "down", "left", "up", "up") from the central cell, the robot will perform one command, then the next command will force him to cross the edge. If the robot starts moving from the cell (2, 1) (second row, first column) then all commands will be executed successfully and the robot will stop at the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

<image> The robot starts from cell (2, 1) (second row, first column). It moves right, right, down, left, up, and up. In this case it ends in the cell (1, 2) (first row, second column).

Identify the cell from which the robot should begin its movement in order to carry out as many commands as possible. Maximize the execution of commands by determining the optimal starting position.

Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

Example

Input


4
1 1
L
1 2
L
3 3
RRDLUU
4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output


1 1
1 2
2 1
3 2

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position and maximum commands executed
        max_commands_executed = 0
        best_starting_position = (1, 1)
        
        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                # Simulate the robot's movement from the current starting position
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0
                
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1
                    
                    # Check if the robot falls off the board
                    if current_row < 1 or current_row > n or current_col < 1 or current_col > m:
                        break
                    
                    # Increment the count of successfully executed commands
                    commands_executed += 1
                
                # Update the best starting position if a new position allows more commands to be executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    best_starting_position = (start_row, start_col)
        
        # Append the best starting position for the current test case
        results.append(best_starting_position)
    
    return results

# Input interface
# Read number of test cases

    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    s = input().strip()
    test_cases.append((n, m, s))

# Output interface
for result in results:
    print(result[0], result[1])

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        # Initialize variables to track the best starting position and maximum commands executed
        max_commands_executed = 0
        best_starting_position = (1, 1)
        
        # Iterate over all possible starting positions on the board
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                # Simulate the robot's movement from the current starting position
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0
                
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1
                    
                    # Check if the robot is still on the board
                    if 1 <= current_row <= n and 1 <= current_col <= m:
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break
                
                # Update the best starting position if a new maximum is found
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    best_starting_position = (start_row, start_col)
        
        # Append the best starting position for the current test case
        results.append(best_starting_position)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))
    
    # Output interface
    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)
    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    """Finds the optimal starting position for the robot to execute the maximum number of commands.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, str]]): List of test cases, each containing the board dimensions and command sequence.

    Returns:
        List[Tuple[int, int]]: List of optimal starting positions for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        max_commands = 0
        best_position = (1, 1)

        # Iterate over each possible starting position
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0

                # Simulate the robot's movement
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1

                    # Check if the robot is out of bounds
                    if current_row < 1 or current_row > n or current_col < 1 or current_col > m:
                        break

                    commands_executed += 1

                # Update the best position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands:
                    max_commands = commands_executed
                    best_position = (start_row, start_col)

        results.append(best_position)

    return results

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))

    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)
    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, m, commands in test_cases:
        max_commands_executed = 0
        optimal_start = (1, 1)
        
        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0
                
                # Simulate the robot's movement
                for command in commands:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1
                    
                    # Check if the robot is still on the board
                    if 1 <= current_row <= n and 1 <= current_col <= m:
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break
                
                # Update the optimal starting position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    optimal_start = (start_row, start_col)
        
        results.append(optimal_start)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    test_cases = []
    index = 1
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, data[index].split())
        s = data[index + 1].strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))
        index += 2
    
    # Call the function
    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        print(result[0], result[1])

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    """Finds the optimal starting position for the robot on a checkered board.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing the dimensions of the board (n, m) and the command sequence (s).

    Returns:
        A list of tuples, each containing the optimal starting position (row, column) for each test case.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        # Edge case for 1x1 board
        if n == 1 and m == 1:
            results.append((1, 1))
            continue

        max_commands_executed = 0
        best_position = (1, 1)

        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0

                # Simulate robot movement
                for command in s:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1

                    # Check boundary conditions
                    if current_row < 1 or current_row > n or current_col < 1 or current_col > m:
                        break

                    commands_executed += 1

                # Update best position if a new maximum is found
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    best_position = (start_row, start_col)

        results.append(best_position)

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))

    # Output interface
    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)
    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    results = []
    
    for n, m, commands in test_cases:
        max_executed = 0
        optimal_position = (1, 1)
        
        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                executed_commands = 0
                
                # Simulate the robot's movement
                for command in commands:
                    if command == 'L':
                        current_col -= 1
                    elif command == 'R':
                        current_col += 1
                    elif command == 'U':
                        current_row -= 1
                    elif command == 'D':
                        current_row += 1
                    
                    # Check if the robot is still on the board
                    if 1 <= current_row <= n and 1 <= current_col <= m:
                        executed_commands += 1
                    else:
                        break
                
                # Update the optimal starting position if a new maximum is found
                if executed_commands > max_executed:
                    max_executed = executed_commands
                    optimal_position = (start_row, start_col)
        
        results.append(optimal_position)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))
    
    # Output interface
    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)
    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    results = []
    
    # Define movement deltas for each command
    move_deltas = {
        'L': (0, -1),
        'R': (0, 1),
        'U': (-1, 0),
        'D': (1, 0)
    }
    
    for n, m, s in test_cases:
        max_commands_executed = 0
        best_starting_position = (1, 1)
        
        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0
                
                # Simulate the robot's movement
                for command in s:
                    delta_row, delta_col = move_deltas[command]
                    new_row = current_row + delta_row
                    new_col = current_col + delta_col
                    
                    # Check if the new position is within bounds
                    if 1 <= new_row <= n and 1 <= new_col <= m:
                        current_row, current_col = new_row, new_col
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break
                
                # Update the best starting position if more commands are executed
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    best_starting_position = (start_row, start_col)
        
        results.append(best_starting_position)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))
    
    # Output interface
    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)
    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple

def find_optimal_starting_position(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, str]]) -> List[Tuple[int, int]]:
    results = []
    
    # Define movement deltas for each command
    move_deltas = {
        'L': (0, -1),
        'R': (0, 1),
        'U': (-1, 0),
        'D': (1, 0)
    }
    
    for n, m, commands in test_cases:
        max_commands_executed = 0
        best_starting_position = (1, 1)
        
        # Iterate over all possible starting positions
        for start_row in range(1, n + 1):
            for start_col in range(1, m + 1):
                current_row, current_col = start_row, start_col
                commands_executed = 0
                
                # Simulate the robot's movement
                for command in commands:
                    delta_row, delta_col = move_deltas[command]
                    new_row = current_row + delta_row
                    new_col = current_col + delta_col
                    
                    # Check if the new position is within bounds
                    if 1 <= new_row <= n and 1 <= new_col <= m:
                        current_row, current_col = new_row, new_col
                        commands_executed += 1
                    else:
                        break
                
                # Update the best starting position if a new maximum is found
                if commands_executed > max_commands_executed:
                    max_commands_executed = commands_executed
                    best_starting_position = (start_row, start_col)
        
        results.append(best_starting_position)
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        s = input().strip()
        test_cases.append((n, m, s))
    
    # Call the function and print results
    results = find_optimal_starting_position(t, test_cases)
    for r, c in results:
        print(r, c)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
plans:
requirement analysis:
The requirements focus on maximizing the number of commands executed by the robot without falling off the board. The solution must efficiently determine the optimal starting position for the robot, especially given the constraints of large board sizes and command sequences. The algorithm should be robust enough to handle multiple test cases and provide accurate results for each.
requirement pool:
- Develop an algorithm to determine the optimal starting position for the robot.
- Ensure the robot executes the maximum number of commands without falling.
- Optimize the solution for large input sizes.
- Handle multiple test cases efficiently.
- Provide flexibility in choosing any optimal starting position if multiple exist.
We will implement a function to determine the optimal starting position for the robot on a checkered board. The function will simulate the robot's movements based on the given command sequence and check each possible starting position to find the one that allows the maximum number of commands to be executed without falling off the board. Given the constraints of large board sizes and command sequences, the solution will be optimized to handle these efficiently. We will use basic Python data structures and algorithms to achieve this.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'checkered rectangular board'
    Explanation: The board is a grid with n rows and m columns, where the robot can move from one cell to another adjacent cell.

    'sequence of commands'
    Explanation: A string consisting of 'L', 'R', 'D', 'U' that dictates the robot's movement direction.

    'optimal starting position'
    Explanation: The position on the board where the robot can execute the maximum number of commands without falling off the board.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'as many commands as possible': means maximizing the number of commands executed without the robot falling off the board.

# [degree adverb]
    'maximum': means finding the starting position that allows the greatest number of commands to be executed successfully.

# [code logic]
    1. Parse the input to get the number of test cases and details for each test case.
    2. For each test case, initialize variables to track the best starting position and maximum commands executed.
    3. Simulate the robot's movement from each possible starting position on the board.
    4. For each starting position, execute the sequence of commands and check if the robot falls off the board.
    5. Track the number of successfully executed commands for each starting position.
    6. Update the best starting position if a new position allows more commands to be executed.
    7. Output the best starting position for each test case.

# [edge case]
    Test case with a 1x1 board and a command that moves out of bounds:
    Input: 1 1 L
    Output: 1 1
    Explanation: The robot cannot move anywhere without falling off, so any starting position is valid.

    Test case with a command sequence longer than the board dimensions:
    Input: 2 2 LURD
    Output: 1 1
    Explanation: The robot can start at (1,1) and execute all commands without falling off.

    Test case with multiple optimal starting positions:
    Input: 3 3 RRDLUU
    Output: 2 1
    Explanation: Starting at (2,1) allows all commands to be executed successfully.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of simulating movements from all possible starting positions inherently handles these scenarios.

2. Initialize variables to track the best starting position and the maximum number of commands executed.
3. Iterate over each possible starting cell (r, c) on the board.

   - Track the current position of the robot.

5. Compare the number of successful commands for each starting position and update the best starting position if a new maximum is found.
6. Output the best starting position for each test case.

# [edge case] 
    1 1
    L = 1 1
    Explanation: The board is 1x1, so any command will cause the robot to fall off immediately. The only starting position is (1, 1).

    RR = 1 1
    Explanation: On a 2x2 board, starting at (1, 1) allows executing no commands successfully since any move will cause a fall.

    3 3
    UUU = 3 1
    Explanation: Starting at (3, 1) allows executing all commands successfully since moving up three times from row 3 will not cause a fall.

    Output: 2 1

requirement analysis:
The main requirement is to determine the optimal starting position on a board for a robot to execute a sequence of commands without falling off. The solution must handle large board sizes and command sequences efficiently, ensuring maximum command execution.
requirement pool:
- Determine the optimal starting position for maximum command execution.
- Handle large board sizes and command sequences efficiently.
- Provide multiple valid starting positions if applicable.
- Ensure the solution is scalable for up to 10^6 commands.
- Optimize the algorithm for speed and memory usage.
We will implement a function that simulates the robot's movement on the board. The function will iterate over all possible starting positions on the board and simulate the execution of the command sequence from each position. It will track the number of commands successfully executed before the robot falls off the board. The optimal starting position will be the one that allows the maximum number of commands to be executed. Given the constraints, we will ensure the solution is efficient by avoiding unnecessary recalculations and using simple arithmetic to track the robot's position.
Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'checkered rectangular board'
    Explanation: This refers to the grid-like structure of the board where the robot can move. Each cell on the board can be identified by its row and column indices.

    'sequence of commands'
    Explanation: This is the list of movements ('L', 'R', 'D', 'U') that the robot will execute in order.

    'optimal starting position'
    Explanation: The starting cell on the board from which the robot can execute the maximum number of commands without falling off the board.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'as many commands as possible': The goal is to maximize the number of commands executed without the robot falling off the board.

# [degree adverb] 
    'maximum': Refers to executing the highest possible number of commands from a starting position without falling off.

# [code logic]
1. Parse the input to get the number of test cases.
2. For each test case, read the dimensions of the board (n, m) and the sequence of commands (s).
3. Initialize variables to track the best starting position and the maximum number of commands executed.
4. Iterate over all possible starting positions on the board.
5. For each starting position, simulate the robot's movement according to the command sequence.
6. Track the robot's position and check if it falls off the board after each command.
7. If a command causes the robot to fall, stop executing further commands from that starting position.
8. Compare the number of successfully executed commands with the current maximum and update if necessary.
9. After checking all positions, output the best starting position for each test case.

# [edge case] 
    1 1
    L
    = 1 1
    Explanation: The board is 1x1, so any move will cause the robot to fall. The only possible starting position is (1, 1).

    2 2
    RR
    = 1 1
    Explanation: Starting at (1, 1), any move right will cause a fall. The robot can only execute one command successfully.

    3 3
    UUU
    = 3 1
    Explanation: Starting at (3, 1), moving up three times will keep the robot within bounds, executing all commands successfully.

We will implement a function that simulates the robot's movement on the board. The function will return the starting position that allows the maximum number of commands to be executed. Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'checkered rectangular board'
    Explanation: This refers to the grid-like structure of the board where the robot can move. Each cell on the board can be identified by its row and column indices.

    'sequence of commands'
    Explanation: This is the list of movements ('L', 'R', 'D', 'U') that the robot will execute in order.

    'optimal starting position'
    Explanation: The starting cell from which the robot can execute the maximum number of commands without falling off the board.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    'as many commands as possible': This means maximizing the number of commands executed without the robot falling off the board.

# [degree adverb] 
    'maximum': Refers to executing the highest possible number of commands from a starting position without falling off.

# [code logic]
1. Parse the input to get the number of test cases.
2. For each test case, read the dimensions of the board and the sequence of commands.
3. Initialize variables to track the best starting position and the maximum number of commands executed.
4. Iterate over all possible starting positions on the board.
5. For each starting position, simulate the robot's movement according to the command sequence.
6. Track the number of commands executed before the robot falls off.
7. Update the best starting position if a new maximum is found.
8. Output the best starting position for each test case.

# [edge case] 
    Test case 1: 1 1, L = 1 1
    Explanation: The board is 1x1, any move will cause a fall, so starting at (1,1) is optimal as no commands can be executed.

    Test case 2: 2 2, RR = 1 1
    Explanation: The board is 2x2, starting at (1,1) allows executing one 'R' before falling off.

    Test case 3: 3 3, UUU = 3 1
    Explanation: Starting at (3,1) allows executing all 'U' commands without falling off.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle edge cases. The logic inherently handles all possible scenarios by simulating movements from each possible starting position and checking boundary conditions.
examples:
Input

The first line contains an integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of test cases.

The next 2t lines contain descriptions of the test cases.

In the description of each test case, the first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6) — the height and width of the field that the robot is located on. The second line of the description is a string s consisting solely of characters 'L', 'R', 'D' and 'U' — the sequence of commands the robot executes. The string has a length from 1 to 10^6 commands.

It is guaranteed that the total length of s over all test cases does not exceed 10^6.

Output

Print t lines, each of which contains the answer to the corresponding test case. The answer to the test case are two integers r (1 ≤ r ≤ n) and c (1 ≤ c ≤ m), separated by a space — the coordinates of the cell (row number and column number) from which the robot should start moving to perform as many commands as possible.

If there are several such cells, you may output any of them.

Example

Input


4
1 1
L
1 2
L
3 3
RRDLUU
4 3
LUURRDDLLLUU


Output


1 1
1 2
2 1
3 2
